Context: The George Brown College community observes the National Day of Remembrance and Action Against Gender-based Violence on December 6. In 1989, 14 women were murdered at Montreal’s École Polytechnique, with victims targeted for studying engineering. Acknowledged are the thousands of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls across Canada and recent incidents like a stabbing at the University of Waterloo. The event was hosted by the Office of Anti-Racism, Equity and Human Rights Services (OAREHRS) and Assaulted Women and Children’s Counselor/Advocate (AWCCA) program. Speakers included Toronto Mayor Oliva Chow, GBC President Dr. Gervan Fearon, and Community Services and Health Sciences Dean Patricia Chorney Rubin. Dr. Fearon emphasized fostering an inclusive environment free of harassment and discrimination. The AWCCA program, Canada's only one of its kind, has prepared students to support survivors of gender-based violence for over 30 years. Students recognized at the event were Geneviève Bergeron, Hélène Colgan, Nathalie Croteau, Barbara Daigneault, Anne-Marare Edward, Maud Haviernick, Maryse Laganière, Maryse Leclair, Anne-Marie Lemay, Sonia Pelletier, Michèle Richard, Annie St-Arneault, and Annie Turcotte. Contact information: 416-415-2000, TTY: 1-877-515-5559, ask.george@georgebrown.ca.
